questions.neutral: You look like you dodged something - true?

hobby.message: Any luck fixing the old typewriter?

wrong_hobby_answer: That's not me. In free time, I take analog photographs. They capture the truth in a way that digital can't.
neutral_answer: Just got through another checkpoint, nothing new.
I spend time on street photography. Analog film only.
Feels like the city is a bit more chaotic now.
Hard to get a clear shot with all these crowds.
You could say that. Streets are different tonight.
I work with 35mm film, shoot whatever catches my eye.
Analog keeps me honest. No reruns, no edits.
Snapped a few shots during the chaos earlier.
People aren’t as camera-shy lately.
Yeah, dodged a couple drones on my way here.
I shoot analog street photography—real 35mm, smuggled if I can get it.
Capturing truth, not compliance. Makes things interesting.
After Halden’s mess, faces on the street changed overnight.
Even the checkpoints seemed distracted tonight.
Perfect timing to get a few honest frames.
You caught me. The city is off-kilter—perfect for my kind of work.
I do analog street photography—real film, old school.
I was out during those celebration riots, camera hidden in my coat.
People actually asked to be photographed. That’s never happened before.
Usually the BCI would flag me for ‘noncompliant movement.’ Not tonight.
Whole routine was off. Like nobody knew the rules anymore.
Makes me wonder what truth looks like when no one's watching.
Definitely dodged something—security, algorithms, whatever's left of them now.
I’m obsessed with analog street photography. I hunt down smuggled 35mm rolls whenever I can.
Used to be risky as hell. BCI loves pattern violations and privacy is a rumor here.
But tonight, after all the hype over Halden’s predictions, everyone’s distracted—perfect cover.
Snapped honest shots of protests, people daring to drop their masks, the whole city uncertain.
Usually I hide my film. Tonight, strangers handed me their stories like they wanted to be seen.
Guess they trust me to remember for them. That’s new. Feels dangerous, but real.
For a few hours, I’m not ghosting anyone—I’m archiving what the BCI always misses.
hobby_answer: Still shooting film. Keeps me busy.
City’s been strange. Harder to find quiet spots lately.
People in the crowds act different since that Council stunt.
Security drones ignore me sometimes, sometimes just hover. Unpredictable.
Film’s getting tougher to get, too.
Yeah. Still prefer film to feeds. Honest mistakes, you know.
Hobby’s more complicated with all the new rumors about Halden’s journal.
Used to wait for shifts in patrols, now it’s chaos.
Crowds want their moment caught now, not staged propaganda.
Whenever the system glitches, the light in the city changes, too.
Feels like everyone's waiting for the next crackdown.
Absolutely. Nothing digital matches 35mm grain in low city light.
That night of the celebrations, I shot two rolls—everyone acted unfiltered for once.
People asked for portraits, not like before when they dodged cameras.
BCI glitched, so I explored places I’d usually avoid.
The underpass crowds felt real, not posed or staged.
After, access locked down again. Like the system realized its slip.
Timing is everything these days.
Definitely. Analog’s my way to record what the system misses—unedited, unnoticed.
Last week, chaos after the Council’s journal leaks let me roam for hours.
No patrols, checkpoints ignored me, citizens actually wanted to be photographed.
I caught unguarded scenes—kids lighting up, elders openly debating, rare moments.
People treated film shots like proof, like maybe history would notice them again.
I developed them in my bathtub—some negatives show things I shouldn’t have seen.
Now things are tightening again. Gaps close fast after they open.
Mom always said to keep my prints hidden till it’s safe.
Always. Film is my insurance and my protest—truth leaks through the grain.
You remember during Halden’s predicted chaos, I shot everywhere: rallies, side streets, council banners falling.
For once, the BCI froze, so nobody stopped me—MIAs even posed.
The system’s eye blinked and suddenly, real life spilled out. Like old times.
Strangers asked for prints, not data. Told me their real names off record.
Had to smuggle fresh rolls in from outside the checkpoints. Worth it.
Some of those shots… You see who was really running things. That doesn’t go in state media.
My flat’s a darkroom now. If the Directorate scans me, they’ll find a city that doesn’t match their database.
Hardest part? Knowing my prints matter more than anything I ever wrote.
